questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the causative organism of vulval warts?
questions.explanation:
The causative agent of vulval warts is the human papillomavirus (HPV). Genital warts/venereal warts/condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of 
the labia majora, perineum, perianal region and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or coalesce to 
form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is 
favoured by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy. HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin called koilocytes, and their 
presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a 
perinuclear halo, as shown below. The diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine 
blue. The abnormal areas of the skin retain the blue dye. These areas are then biopsied for 
histopathological examination. The given image below shows condyloma acuminata: 721 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A young woman presented with the following lesion on her vulva. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image is suggestive of condyloma acuminata that shows cauliflower-like masses of 
tissue on and around the female anogenital region. Condyloma acuminatum is an epidermal manifestation of the human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV is transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosa. The virus invades the cells of 
the epidermal basal layer through microabrasions. However, anogenital HPV infection is almost 
always acquired through sexual contact. Warts are not required for transmission but are highly infectious because of their high viral load. Option B: The image given below shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with a 
characteristic dimple at the centre. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum caused by the pox 
virus. 722 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: The image given below shows firm papules with a rough horny surface. These are seen 
in verruca vulgaris caused by the human papillomavirus type 2. Option D: The image given below shows condyloma lata which is the characteristic feature of 
secondary syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum.

questions.question:
Question 3: 716 
Sold by @itachibot A sexually active woman presents with cauliflower-like lesions on the vulva. The biopsy of the 
lesion is taken and histopathology reveals the following picture. What is the most likely 
causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows koilocytes, a characteristic feature of infection with human papillomavirus 
(HPV). Other features that can also be seen on histology are: • Perinuclear halo 723 
Sold by @itachibot • Multinucleation • Orangeophilic cytoplasm • Acanthosis • Chronic inflammatory infiltrate Option A: Henderson-Paterson bodies are seen in molluscum contagiosum, caused by poxvirus. Option C and D: Cowdry bodies are seen in herpes infection.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following serotypes are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human 
papillomavirus?
questions.explanation:
Serotypes 16 and 18 are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus (HPV). 
It is called Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months. Gardasil/Silgard is the quadrivalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16 and 18 and is 
given at 0, 2 and 6 months. Gardasil 9 is the nonavalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 
58. In 2020 it has received an expanded indication which now includes the prevention of 
oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a treatment option for a patient with genital warts?
questions.explanation: Genital warts are treated by a local application of 25% trichloracetic acid + 5% fluorouracil. Treatment of genital warts includes the local application of: • Podophyllin 25% in alcohol/podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin daily for 4 days (or) • 25% trichloracetic acid +5% fluorouracil daily for 4 days If this fails, the following treatment is given: • Interferon ointment/cream or intralesional interferon injection • Imiquimod cream thrice a week for 4 months If medical treatment fails then cryosurgery, diathermy or laser removal is done.

questions.question:
Question 6: A sexually active woman who presented with an ulcer over the vulva was diagnosed with 
primary syphilis. What is the characteristic feature associated with this condition?

options.a: Non suppurative, tender, and enlarged nodes
options.b: Firm, shotty, and painless nodes that do not suppurate
options.c: Painful, tender, and matted nodes forming an abscess
options.d: Painful, inflamed, necrotic nodes developing a chronic sinus

questions.explanation:
The characteristic feature associated with primary syphilis is firm, shotty, painless nodes that do 
not suppurate. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the motile spirochete, Treponema pallidum. 
In primary syphilis, the classical lesion i.e., chancre appears within 9–90 days from the first 
exposure. 724 
Sold by @itachibot The macular lesion becomes papular and then ulcerates. The ulcer(s) is painless and firm, with a 
punched out base and rolled edges. If left unattended, these heal within 3–9 weeks. It is 
accompanied by painless inguinal discrete lymphadenopathy.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 32-year-old woman known to have syphilis presented with the following lesions over the 
vulva. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows condyloma lata, a classic finding of secondary syphilis. Multiple moist well-demarcated papules and plaques are seen in condyloma lata. They are highly 
contagious, exophytic broad excrescences that ulcerate and are commonly seen on the vulva, 
perianal area and upper thighs.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 26-year-old sexually active man comes to the STD clinic with a painful genital ulcer. On 
examination, the ulcer and the right inguinal lymph nodes were tender. What is the causative 
organism?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi which is a 
gram-negative anaerobe. Chancroid is symptomatic in men. Both ulcer and lymphadenopathy are 
painful. Lymphadenopathy in chancroid is either unilateral or bilateral. Chancroid is generally 
asymptomatic in women but sometimes presents as painful lymphadenopathy. The image below shows a chancroid ulcer with purulent and haemorrhagic discharge. It has 
a non-indurated, erythematous base. 726 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 10: A sexually active man presents with complaints of painful swelling over the inguinal region. 
He also gives a history of a painless genital ulcer that resolved spontaneously. On 
examination, groove sign is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The pathognomic groove sign of Greenblatt is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) 
caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1, L2, L3). This image shows groove sign which is seen in ■ of the cases in the secondary stage of LGV. It 
refers to the depression between the enlarged femoral and inguinal lymph nodes on either side of 
the inguinal ligament. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted disease that causes genital ulcers. It

questions.question:
Question 11: A 20-year-old female sex worker presents with complaints of constipation and blood in stools 
for 3 months. On DRE, a circumferential constriction is felt beyond which the finger cannot 
be advanced. Which of the following is a probable cause for this complication?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rectal stricture which is a complication 
of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1/L2/L3). 
Rectal involvement is commonly seen in women as the primary disease often goes unnoticed and 
untreated. Anorectal involvement causes proctocolitis and causes rectal strictures. This occurs due 
to the contiguous spread of the primary infection from the perirectal nodes leading to scar tissue 
formation. The complications of lymphogranuloma venereum include: • Rectal stricture formation may lead to: • Intestinal obstruction • Rectovaginal fistulae • Proctitis • Vulvar cancer.

questions.question: Question 12: What is the causative agent for granuloma inguinale?
questions.explanation:
The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calymmatobacterium 
granulomatis. It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causing 
chronic ulcerative infection of the vulva. It is highly contagious and transmitted through repeated sexual or non-sexual contact. The 
incubation period is 1-12 weeks. Clinical features: It begins as a painless nodule which later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers that 
tend to coalesce; the vulva is progressively destroyed, and minimal adenopathy may occur. Diagnosis: Microscopic examination of smears from the lesion/ biopsy specimens reveals pathognomonic 
intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies and clusters of bacteria with a bipolar (safety pin) appearance. 728 
Sold by @itachibot Blue-black stained organisms are seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear cells. Management: Azithromycin 1 g orally once per week or 500 mg daily for at least 3 weeks and until all lesions 
have completely healed. The given image below shows the donovanosis in a female patient with a beefy red ulcer:

Question 13: A 19-year-old girl presented with multiple beefy-red ulcers over the labia. Microscopic 
examination of smear from the lesion showed intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and 
gram-negative bacteria having a safety pin appearance. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granuloma inguinale which is caused by a 
gram-negative bacteria, Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red 
painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce and bleed easily on contact. If secondarily infected, 
they may become painful. The ulcers heal by fibrosis, which can result in scarring resembling 
keloids. The lymph nodes are usually uninvolved but can become enlarged. New lesions can appear along 
the lymphatic drainage channels. The gross image below shows granuloma inguinale of the cervix with a beefy red appearance of 
the hypervascular intravaginal tissues. 729 
Sold by @itachibot The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also 
shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance. 730
